Andorra.2.Mitigation pledges: reducing 37% of greenhouse gas emission by 2030 below BAU
Andorra.3.Overall analysis of INDC: Andorra's INDC covers the energy and waste sectors, accounting for 98.5% of the country’s emission. However, it doesn’t intend to use international mechanism to achieve its reduction goal.

Canada.2.Mitigation pledges: reducing 30% of greenhouse gas emission by 2030 compared to 2005
Canada.3.Overall analysis of INDC:
Canadian carbon emission accounted for 1.6% of the world and their existing mitigation goal is to reduce the emission by 17% compared to 2005 before 2020. However, based on the calculation, Canadian carbon emission is predicted to raise 1% at 2020 and 8% in 2030 comparing to 2005, respectively.
For Canada to include the land usage and forestry into INDC will raise 11% of the industrial carbon emission compared to 1990, in addition to 9% oils sand industry emission accounted and its expansion, which both making Canada’s goal unreachable.

China.2.Mitigation pledges:
reaching emission peak before 2030, and lowering carbon intensity (emissions per unit of GDP) by 60% to 65% from the 2005
level by 2030
China.3.Overall analysis of INDC:
Same as the announcement made on APEC 2014, China commits to an emission peak before 2030, also, increase the share of non-fossil fuels in primary energy consumption to 20%. However, what comes as a fresh pledge is committing to lower carbon intensity (emissions per unit of GDP) by 60% to 65% from the 2005 level. Nevertheless, China committing to a reduction of “emission intensity” rather than “GHG emission” indicates that its ambition is prone to be influenced by the economy.
China also reaffirms its support to the application of Common But Differentiated Responsibility (CBDR) in the Agreement, which implies developed countries such as USA and EU have more responsibilities on climate actions, and should help developing countries on adaptation. Also, China supports the Agreement to be a legal-binding one.

Ethiopia.2.Mitigation pledges: reducing 64% of greenhouse gas emission by 2030 below BAU
Ethiopia.3.Overall analysis of INDC:
Ethiopia’s INDC is the first to break down reductions that different sectors will be responsible of respectively. Also, Ethiopia proposes four pillars to mitigate emission, which includes improving crop and living stock production practices, re-establishing forests, expanding renewable energy, and transiting to modern and energy efficient technologies. 
As for adaptation, Ethiopia addresses variousmeasures such as improving crop varieties, enhancing irrigation systems, rehabilitating degraded forests, and so on to deal with drought, flood, and cross-cutting intervention. Further, it mentions further research on international financial and technical support required and quantifying the cost of countering social, environmental and economic vulnerabilities.

Europen Union.2.Mitigation pledges: reducing 40% of greenhouse gas emission by 2030 compared to 1990
Europen Union.3.Overall analysis of INDC:
European Union, has turned in its INDC as a regional organization. It’s emphasized that all the emission reduction will be conducted voluntarily within the region instead of using credits from international mechanism. However, the percentage and the calculation in terms of Land Use, Land Use Change, and Forestry are both rather vague. As a result, this weakens the intended commitment from EU.
On the other hand, EU did not address the important issues such as technology, trade, climate financing and adaptation plan in its INDC. Additionally, EU proposed during the previous negotiation that the new agreement ought to include a "5-year periodic review" mechanism as a proposal. Nevertheless, the mitigation pledges for 2025 are not included in its INDC.

Gabon.2.Mitigation pledges: reducing 50% of greenhouse gas emission by 2025 below BAU
Gabon.3.Overall analysis of INDC:
Gabon was the first African country, also the first Low-Developed Country to submit its INDC. Its mitigation pledge roughly equals cutting emission back to the level in 2000 by 2025.
Focusing on land and energy programmes, Gabon also intends to set up a national market for carbon offset. Moreover, adaptation plans including coastal area protection are mentioned in the document.

Iceland.3.Overall analysis of INDC: Rather than proposing reduction pledges, Iceland submits an INDC committing to the EU 40% reduction target, saying it will ensure the fulfillment of its fair share to the collective delivery. Despite not a member of EU, Iceland has participated in the EU Emission Trade System since 2007. Also, it pledges to implement the same framework as the EU to cut emissions in non-ETS sectors.

Liechtenstein.2.Mitigation pledges: reducing 40% of greenhouse gas emission by 2030 compared to 1990
Liechtenstein.3.Overall analysis of INDC: Liechtenstein, submitted an INDC which the mitigation pledge is consistent with the EU. It also mentioned to coordinate domestic policies concerning energy, transportation, agriculture, and forestry to update its national climate change strategies by 2016.

Mexico.2.Mitigation pledges: reaching net emission peak by 2026; reducing 22% of greenhouse gas emission by 2030 below 2013 BAU
Mexico.3.Overall analysis of INDC:
Mexico is the first developing country in the world to turn in its INDC. The long-term mitigation pledges is set based on its national law of LGCC (General Law on Climate Change/LEY GENERAL DE CAMBIO CLIMÁTICO), which promised to reduce 50% of greenhouse gas emission by 2050 compared to 2000.              
Moreover, not only Mexico has played a pioneer role of the developing countries, but also Mexican INDC has taken consideration in gender perspective as well as human right equity, which are topics absent from the European INDCs . Also, adaptation plan including establishing climate resilient infrastructure, building early alert system, and reaching zero deforestation by 2030 are all included in the Mexican INDC.

Morocco.2.Mitigation pledges: reducing 32% of greenhouse gas emission by 2030 below BAU
Morocco.3.Overall analysis of INDC:
As the host for next year’s COP22, Morocco is the second country (after Mexico) to submit its INDC including conditional and unconditional reduction targets. The country called for international support on climate finance, such as via Green Climate Fund, to achieve its conditional target of an additional 19% reduction.
It also includes the adaptation plan outlining vision, goals, needs, and system for monitoring and evaluation.

Norway.2.Mitigation pledges: reducing 40% of greenhouse gas emission by 2030 compared to 1990
Norway.3.Overall analysis of INDC: Norway clearly stated that the final choice of land sector accounting will not affect the original pledging ambition. They also intend to fulfill the commitment via a collective delivery with the EU instead of through individual countries. Therefore, Norway emphasizes the importance of including market based mechanisms in the Paris Agreement, and the opportunity to continuing the use of CDM and JI.

Republic of Serbia.2.Mitigation pledges: reducing 9.8% of greenhouse gas emission by 2030 compared to 1990
Republic of Serbia.3.Overall analysis of INDC: As a non-Annex I party to the Kyoto Protocol, Serbia, however, submits its INDC with a binding reduction target. Nevertheless, according to the latest report from the country, its 2013 emission is 25% below their 1990 level, which means its INDC reduction target actually allows a 15% emission increase by 2030. Further, Serbia’s INDC mentions the damage extreme weather (especially droughts, high temperature, and floods) has brought to Serbia, in agriculture, hydrology, forestry, health, and biodiversity sector, including financial losses exceeding 5 billion Euros since 2000. Thus, Serbia becomes the first countries to address the issue of Loss and Damage in its INDC, saying 68 million dollars has already been invested since 2000, but no long-term investment plan mentioned.

Russia.2.Mitigation pledges: reducing 25-30% of greenhouse gas emission by 2025 compared to 1990
Russia.3.Overall analysis of INDC:
The mitigationemission goal of Russia is far away from the global collectiveinternational common goal of preventing temperature increment to rise by 2 ℃. The Russian goal actually indicates a 30-38% emission rise by 2025 when compared to 2012.emission in 2025 is 30-38% more than that in 2012, if they base on 2012.
Also, Russia did not mention about the adaptation plan in its INDC. say nothing on adaptive strategy. The northern Russian is close to the Arctic and the forestry area in Russia accounts for 25% of that in the world., butHowever, having nothey don’t have any clear planpolicy on adaptationis proposed  leaves Russia's climate resilienceso that there adaptive abilities to people and biodiversity on extreme climate are doubted.

Singapore.2.Mitigation pledges: reaching emission peak before 2030, and lowering carbon intensity (emissions per unit of GDP) by 36% from the 2005 level by 2030
Singapore.3.Overall analysis of INDC:
Singapore’s INDC seems to put much anticipation on advancing its future energy efficiency, for that renewables are viewed as limited due to the national circumstances in its proposal. As one of the smallest countries in the world, LULUCF merely accounts for nothing. Also, the country doesn’t intend to use credit from international market, for there’s still too much uncertainty, according to the officials. However, it doesn’t mention the emission from the international shipping, despite being the world’s second busiest port.
As for adaptation, Singapore emphasizes its potential challenges of food and water security, coastline protection and such. It also proposed some measures to increase its resilience such as regional climate modelling, applying innovative technology for prevention and management, periodic review on building resilience, and so on.

South Korea.2.Mitigation pledges: reducing 37% of greenhouse gas emission by 2030 below BAU
South Korea.3.Overall analysis of INDC:
As a highly-developed country, South Korea, however, doesn’t submit an INDC with a binding reduction target. Instead, its pledge of a 37% reduction under BAU, despite better than the 14.7% to 31.3% proposed before, is actually 81% above 1990 emission levels excluding land-use, land-use change and forestry (LULUCF). South Korea intends to achieve 11.3% of this target by using carbon credits from international market mechanism, however details are not specified.
Adaptation is also mentioned in South Korea’s INDC, promoting Climate Friendly and Safe Society via strengthening climate change infrastructure, transiting to climate-resilient social and economic structure and so on.

Switzerland.2.Mitigation pledges: reducing 35% of greenhouse gas emission by 2025, 50% by 2030, 70-85%by 2050 compared to 1990
Switzerland.3.Overall analysis of INDC: Switzerland, out of all member states, was the first one to submit its INDC, with high marks on information transparency. However, according to the suggestion from IPCC, the mitigation pledges from Switzerland only reaches the lowest criteria of its reduction capability and responsibility. In addition, Switzerland will include Land Use, Land Use Change, and Forestry into its mitigation framework. On top of that, carbon credits from international mechanism will partly be used. This indicates that the domestic emission reduction within Switzerland would not cover the majority of total expected emission reduction.

United States of America.2.Mitigation pledges: reducing 17% of greenhouse gas emission by 2020, 26-28% by 2025 compared to 2005
United States of America.3.Overall analysis of INDC: The United States, as the second largest carbon emitter in the world, turned in the INDC with a long term goal of 80% drop of carbon emission before 2050. Since the United States withdrew from the Kyoto Protocol, its passive attitude toward climate change has suffered a lot of criticism. However, things start to change after President Obama stepped up. In addition to the joint climate statement made with China’s President Xi Jinping during 2014 APEC, in March 2015, Obama also announced that the federal government itself committinghas to reduce 40% of greenhouse gas emission by 2025 compared to 2005.the emission in 2025 to the level which is 40% less than that in 2005, This actionto demonstrates for other domestic carbon emission sector, hoping to get the dominance of negotiations in COP21. All these actions show the relatively active attitude of Obama government toward climate change, and its eagerness to gain an advantageous status during COP21 taking place later in the year.
